issue.title: Write linter to check file permissions
issue.body:
Would be nice to have a linter to check that only files with a hash-bang may set the executable flag. See #21728

#### Useful skills:

* git
* Bash
* Python
* Our linter scripts in `./test/lint`

#### Want to work on this issue?

For guidance on contributing, please read [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) before opening your pull request.

events.body:
Perhaps this can be used as a starting point.

It should most probably be ported to Python to become portable, maintainable and readable.

Tested under Linux. I don't think it will work under macOS (BSD `file` and `stat` differences), but I don't have any Mac to test on :)

```bash
#!/bin/bash

export LC_ALL=C

ALLOWED_PERMISSION_NON_EXECUTABLES=644
ALLOWED_PERMISSION_EXECUTABLES=755
ALLOWED_FILENAME_REGEXP='^[a-zA-Z0-9/_.@][a-zA-Z0-9/_.@-]*$'

set -e

# cd to root folder of git repo for git ls-files to work properly
cd "$(dirname $0)/../.." || exit 1

REPO_FILES=$(git ls-files)

if grep -vE "${ALLOWED_FILENAME_REGEXP}" <<< "${REPO_FILES}"; then
    echo "^ There exists filenames in the repo which do not match the allowed filename regexp ${ALLOWED_FILENAME_REGEXP}. Failing."
    exit 1
fi

EXIT_CODE=0

NON_STANDARD_PERMISSION_FILENAME_PAIRS=$(find ${REPO_FILES} \! -perm ${ALLOWED_PERMISSION_NON_EXECUTABLES} -printf "%m:%p\n")
for PERMISSION_FILENAME_PAIR in ${NON_STANDARD_PERMISSION_FILENAME_PAIRS}; do
    PERMISSION=$(cut -f1 -d: <<< "${PERMISSION_FILENAME_PAIR}")
    FILENAME=$(cut -f2 -d: <<< "${PERMISSION_FILENAME_PAIR}")
    if [[ ${PERMISSION} == "${ALLOWED_PERMISSION_EXECUTABLES}" ]]; then
        SHEBANG=$(head -c2 "${FILENAME}")
        if [[ ${SHEBANG} == "#!" ]]; then
            continue
        fi
        echo "Error: File ${FILENAME} has permission ${ALLOWED_PERMISSION_EXECUTABLES} (executable) and is thus expected to contain a shebang '#!'. Add shebang or do \"chmod ${ALLOWED_PERMISSION_NON_EXECUTABLES} ${FILENAME}\" to make it non-executable."
        EXIT_CODE=1
    else
        echo "Error: File ${FILENAME} has unexpected permission ${PERMISSION}. Do \"chmod ${ALLOWED_PERMISSION_NON_EXECUTABLES} ${FILENAME}\" (if non-executable) or \"chmod ${ALLOWED_PERMISSION_EXECUTABLES} ${FILENAME}\" (if executable)."
        EXIT_CODE=1
    fi
done

exit ${EXIT_CODE}
```
`if [ -x filename ]` is a portable (in a POSIX sense) way to check the executable flag of a file.

Here is a first pass at a python version

```python3
#!/usr/bin/env python3
# Copyright (c) 2021 The Bitcoin Core developers
# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.

"""
This checks that all files in the repository have correct names and permissions
"""

import os
import re
import sys
from subprocess import check_output

ALLOWED_PERMISSION_NON_EXECUTABLES = 644
ALLOWED_PERMISSION_EXECUTABLES = 755
ALLOWED_FILENAME_REGEXP = '^[a-zA-Z0-9/_.@][a-zA-Z0-9/_.@-]*$'
CMD_REPO_FILES = 'git ls-files'


def check_files():
    files = check_output(CMD_REPO_FILES, shell=True).decode('utf8').strip().split('\n')
    filename_regex = re.compile(ALLOWED_FILENAME_REGEXP)
    for file in files:
        # Check file name
        if not filename_regex.match(file):
            print(f"'{file}' does not not match the allowed filename regexp. Failing.")
            sys.exit(1)

        # Check file permissions
        file_perms = int(oct(os.stat(file).st_mode)[-3:])
        if file_perms == ALLOWED_PERMISSION_EXECUTABLES:
            shebang = open(file, "r").readline(2)
            if shebang == '#!':
                continue
            print(f"File '{file}' has permission {ALLOWED_PERMISSION_EXECUTABLES} (executable) and is thus expected to contain a shebang '#!'. Add shebang or do \"chmod {ALLOWED_PERMISSION_NON_EXECUTABLES} {file}\" to make it non-executable.")
            sys.exit(1)
        elif file_perms == ALLOWED_PERMISSION_NON_EXECUTABLES:
            continue
        else:
            print(f"File '{file}' has unexpected permission {file_perms}. Do \"chmod {ALLOWED_PERMISSION_NON_EXECUTABLES} {file}\" (if non-executable) or \"chmod {ALLOWED_PERMISSION_EXECUTABLES} {file}\" (if executable).")
            sys.exit(1)


def main():
    check_files()


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

You likely already found this in your testing @practicalswift, but it seems that https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/contrib/gitian-descriptors/assign_DISTNAME currently is executable, but missing a shebang line. I could not find any other files with an issue.

Let me know if the above looks anywhere close to acceptable, and I will look into what I need to do to open a proper PR. It would be my first code contribution to Bitcoin Core :)

@windsok 

Nice! Your Python script is portable, maintainable and readable which cannot be said about my hacky `bash` script :) Thanks for taking on the task!

Name is say `test/lint/lint-file-permissions.py` and call it from a shell wrapper `test/lint/lint-file-permissions.sh` (to make it automatically invoked by `test/lint/lint-all.sh`) like this …

```sh
#!/usr/bin/env bash

export LC_ALL=C

set -e
cd "$(dirname $0)/../.."
test/lint/lint-file-permissions.py
```

… and we should be ready to go! I'm ready to review :)

@windsok

Below is a small diff which addresses three small nits - feel free to use or ignore :)

* Now prints all errors encountered (instead exiting after the first error is encountered)
* Now opening files in mode `rb` instead of `r` in order to not fail on non-ASCII files (locale dependent)
* Now prints the allowed filename regexp in case of a non-allowed filename to make remedy easier

```diff
diff --git a/test/lint/lint-file-permissions.py b/test/lint/lint-file-permissions.py
index eb4021fc3..78278e27b 100755
--- a/test/lint/lint-file-permissions.py
+++ b/test/lint/lint-file-permissions.py
@@ -21,29 +21,31 @@ CMD_REPO_FILES = 'git ls-files'
 def check_files():
     files = check_output(CMD_REPO_FILES, shell=True).decode('utf8').strip().split('\n')
     filename_regex = re.compile(ALLOWED_FILENAME_REGEXP)
+    exit_code = 0
     for file in files:
         # Check file name
         if not filename_regex.match(file):
-            print(f"'{file}' does not not match the allowed filename regexp. Failing.")
-            sys.exit(1)
+            print(f"'{file}' does not not match the allowed filename regexp ('{ALLOWED_FILENAME_REGEXP}').")
+            exit_code = 1

         # Check file permissions
         file_perms = int(oct(os.stat(file).st_mode)[-3:])
         if file_perms == ALLOWED_PERMISSION_EXECUTABLES:
-            shebang = open(file, "r").readline(2)
-            if shebang == '#!':
+            shebang = open(file, "rb").read(2)
+            if shebang == b'#!':
                 continue
             print(f"File '{file}' has permission {ALLOWED_PERMISSION_EXECUTABLES} (executable) and is thus expected to contain a shebang '#!'. Add shebang or do \"chmod {ALLOWED_PERMISSION_NON_EXECUTABLES} {file}\" to make it non-executable.")
-            sys.exit(1)
+            exit_code = 1
         elif file_perms == ALLOWED_PERMISSION_NON_EXECUTABLES:
             continue
         else:
             print(f"File '{file}' has unexpected permission {file_perms}. Do \"chmod {ALLOWED_PERMISSION_NON_EXECUTABLES} {file}\" (if non-executable) or \"chmod {ALLOWED_PERMISSION_EXECUTABLES} {file}\" (if executable).")
-            sys.exit(1)
+            exit_code = 1
+    return exit_code


 def main():
-    check_files()
+    sys.exit(check_files())


 if __name__ == "__main__":
```

Don't forget to run `black` on the file before submitting the PR :)
It might be good to also check that files with the bang *do* have the +x flag set. See also https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/16807/files#r345547050

Thanks @MarcoFalke & @practicalswift ! I will do all of this and get a PR together :)

I also noticed that we have this existing lint test which is checking that executable `.sh` and `.py` files have a specific shebang line. I am thinking that it probably makes sense to also move these tests into this new python test file, so that all similar tests are located in the same test file. Does that make sense to you?

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/test/lint/lint-shebang.sh

We also have this existing lint test which is checking filenames in the repo. I am thinking that we should probably either also consolidate this test into the new python test file, or we should remove the filename checking and leave the new tests to be purely related to permissions and shebang lines?

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/test/lint/lint-filenames.sh

I've opened up a draft PR here: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/21740

Very happy to receive any feedback, and will make change accordingly.

Thanks! :)
